review.title: Tightening LP Relaxations for MAP using Message Passing
review.abstract: Linear Programming (LP) relaxations have become powerful tools for finding the most probable (MAP) configuration in graphical models. These relaxations can be solved efficiently using message-passing algorithms such as belief propagation and, when the relaxation is tight, provably find the MAP configuration. The standard LP relaxation is not tight enough in many real-world problems, however, and this has lead to the use of higher order cluster-based LP relaxations. The computational cost increases exponentially with the size of the clusters and limits the number and type of clusters we can use. We propose to solve the cluster selection problem monotonically in the dual LP, iteratively selecting clusters with guaranteed improvement, and quickly re-solving with the added clusters by reusing the existing solution. Our dual message-passing algorithm finds the MAP configuration in protein sidechain placement, protein design, and stereo problems, in cases where the standard LP relaxation fails.

sections.text: Linear programming (LP) has evolved into powerful tools to find the most likely (MAP) configuration in graphical models. However, these relaxations can be efficiently solved by message-passing algorithms such as belief propagation and, if relaxation is tight, can be proven to find the MAP configuration. However, standard LP relaxation is not tight enough in many real-world problems, and this has led to the use of cluster-based LP relaxations of a higher order. Calculation costs increase exponentially with the size of the clusters and limit the number and type of clusters we can use. We suggest solving the cluster selection problem monotonically in the dual LP, iteratively selecting clusters with guaranteed improvement, and quickly resolving with the added clusters by reusing the existing solution. Our dual measurement passing algorithm finds the MAP configuration in the areas of prototyping, placement chain, and steroid chain failure.

sections.heading: 4 Related Work
sections.text: Since MPLP is closely related to the Max-product generalized amount propagation (GBP) algorithm, our work can be considered a Max-pursuit method for GBP. This is closely related to the work of Welling [16], who proposed a Region-pursuit method for GBP. Similar to our work, he proposed greedily adding potential clusters from a candidate set. At each iteration, the cluster leading to the greatest change in GBP-free energy was added. He showed excellent results for 2D grids, but with fully connected diagrams, performance actually began to deteriorate with additional clusters. In [17], a heuristic relationship to maximum normality [19] was used as a stop criterion for region tracking to avoid this behavior. In contrast, since we work with the dual function of the LP, we can guarantee monotonal improvements throughout the course of the algorithm.

sections.heading: 5.1 Side-Chain Prediction
sections.text: The problem of lateral prediction is to find the three-dimensional configuration of rotamers that have the backbone structure of a protein [18]. This problem can be considered as the search for the MAP configuration of a paired model, and in [18] the TRBP algorithm [13] was used to find the MAP solution for most of the models studied. However, TRBP could not find the MAP solution for 30 of the models. In previous work [12] we used a cutting-plane algorithm to solve these lateral problems and found the MAP solution for all of them. This required the addition of between 1 and 27 triplets per model. Running time was between 1 minute and 1 hour to solve each problem, with more than half of the LP to be solved.

sections.heading: 5.3 Stereo Vision
sections.text: Given a stereo pair of images, the stereo problem is to find the disparity of each pixel in a reference image, and this disparity can easily be translated into depth by the camera. The best algorithms currently known for the stereo problem are those that minimize a global energy function [10], which is equivalent to searching for a MAP configuration in a paired model. In our experiments, we use the paired model described in [18] and apply our method to the "tsukuba" sequence, which is reduced in size to contain 116x154 pixels. As there are no connected triplexes in the grid system, we use our method of square clusters.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: To apply LP loosening to real-world problems, one needs to find an efficient way to add clusters to the basic relaxation so that the problem remains comprehensible, but allows a better approximation to the MAP value. In this paper, we presented a greedy limit minimization algorithm on the dual LP to solve this problem, and showed that it has all the necessary ingredients: an efficient algorithm for message delivery, a "warm-start" of the next iteration using current beliefs, and a monotonously decreasing constraint on the MAP. We showed that the algorithm works well in practice, finding the MAP configurations for many real-world problems that we previously thought were too difficult to solve for known methods. While in this paper we focused primarily on adding triplet clusters, our approach is general and can also be used to add larger clusters as long as the messages can be calculated efficiently in the algorithm algorithm.
